title: Life in Donostia: Transportation
text:
Note





Please read this guide to the LCT in Spain written by previous students

title: Life in Donostia: Transportation
text:
Walking
For many of us, Donostia was one of the most beautiful cities we had lived in. It is really worth exploring it by yourself.
The beaches, the architecture, the food, it is all worth trying out.

title: Life in Donostia: Transportation
text:
Bus

The main mode of transportation inside Donostia is the bus.
Use the DBUS app to get the bus time tables. Google Maps is not trustworthy in Donostia.
On a bus, you can pay by cash, credit or debit card, or a local transportation card.
The full bus fare it 1.85€ per ride, as of 2023.
If you get a local transportation card, the Mugi Card, you don’t have to pay the full fare.

title: Life in Donostia: Transportation
text:
MUGI Card

This subsection is a copy of what I wrote in a previous post and it is here for completeness, you are free to skip it.


There are three types of Mugi Card:

Personalized Mugi Card: This one has your name and photo. It takes two weeks to get one. The fare per ride is around 0.60€.
Youth Mugi Card: Like the Personalized Mugi Card, but for people under 25. You need empadronamiento for this one. The fare per ride is around 0.40.
Anonymous Mugi Card: The most general Mugi Card. You can just buy and use it. The fare per ride is around 0.80.

All Mugi Cards cost 5.00€.

So, during your first days in Donostia, it is very convenient to just buy an Anonymous Mugi Card and use it until you figure out how to get one of the other ones.

Where to get the Anonymous Mugi Card?
There are a lot of small shops around Donostia where you can buy and charge a Mugi Card. Just walk around until you see one. If you prefer to know a specific place, I know you can buy them in this small library:




Where to charge your Mugi Card?

By cash: in a lot of shops around Donostia. Just walk around and you’ll find them.
By card:

In Kutxabank ATMs
In the central bus station
In the Euskotren (tram) stations




How to get a personalised MUGI card?
The official website does not include instructions in English, as of 2023.
In order to get a personalised MUGI card, as a foreigner, you will have to ask for it in person.
First, go to the MUGI office next to the Amara metro station. Here you will get the appropiate form for requesting a personalized MUGI card.



You can make an appointment in their website, however, this is not mandatory. You can just show up and wait for a while.
Take your passport and an ID photo with you.
They will give you a form for requesting the card. If you are lucky, they will help you fill out the form.

Second, you have to take this form to a shop that handles the delivery of MUGI cards. There are several shops like this around Donostia. One of the shops closest to the Amara station is the small library mentioned above. Here is where you deposit your form and pay 5€.


Third, wait around 10 days for your card to arrive to the shop.
Why is it so complicated? Well, there is an online application process, however, it is designed for Spanish citizens with and official address (empadronamiento). Everybody else has to go through the long process.
Note that, if you are younger than 25 years, then, after you get your empadronamiento, you will be able to get a Youth MUGI card, which gives you an extremely low price.

title: Life in Donostia: Transportation
text:
Bike


Donostia has good bike infrastructure, except in Parte Vieja. Going around the city by bike is worth it, and the view along the beaches is beautiful.
Your best bets to buy a second hand bike are on the Wallapop app and in Facebook Marketplace.
Otherwise, there is a bike sharing service, called DBIZI, where you can reserve bikes using the PBSC App.
The monthly subscription costs around 6€. With the subscription, each ride under 30 minutes costs 0,50€. This time window is very generous, as biking from the center to the University takes around 15 minutes.

title: Life in Donostia: Transportation
text:
Tram / Light metro
The Euskotren, colloquially called “topo”, is the tram connecting Donostia to the districts in the outskirts and the sourrounding towns. You pay with the MUGI card.
It can get you from Hendaye, a French town at the border, to Bilbao.
With a fairly low ticket price, it is very convenient for exploring the areas around Donostia, where the landscapes are beautiful.


The metro station closest to the University is called Lugaritz.

title: Life in Donostia: Transportation
text:
Regional buses


Lurraldebus is a bus company connecting the Gipuzkoa province to other provinces.
This is the more convenient way to get to the sourrounding cities, namely, Bilbao and Vitoria-Gasteiz. The buses come and go frequently (at least one per hour) and work even until late in the weekends.
You can pay the ticket with cash or card at the main bus station, however, paying with the MUGI card the price is much lower.






Note





As of 2024, the MUGI card can also be used to pay for all the public transport in Bilbao.

title: Life in Donostia: Transportation
text:
Airports
There are three airports reasonably close to Donostia.

The “Donostia” Airport, which is really located in the town of Irun, is the closest to Donostia. It is has very few connections, mainly to bigger cities in Spain.

Getting from the city center to the airport takes around 50 minutes by bus.



The Bilbao Airport hosts bigger airlines and several budget airlines. There are regional buses from Donostia to this airport.




The Vitoria-Gasteiz airport, which hosts RyanAir, with a lot of connections. To get to this airport, you can take a regional bus to Vitoria-Gasteiz, taking one hour and a half, and then a bus for 20 minutes.

title: Visa to France - 1: Campus France
text:
Every country has its own educational system. How can the French Government know if the requirements of one country match the requirements in France? This is what Campus France exists for.
Campus France is a service from the French Government dedicated to: - handling the applications of foreing students to French Universities. Since I was coming from an Erasmus Mundus program, I did not have to go through the proccess of applying through Campus France. - analyzing foreign academic qualifications (like university Diplomas) and decide on its equivalent in the French educational system.
After deciding on the qualifications of a candidate, they emit a certificate, which is later used by the French embassy for the Visa application.
Not all countries must go through the Campus France process when applying for a French Visa, for example, Canada has their own procedure.

title: Visa to France - 1: Campus France
text:
A technicality
LCT students get to be registered as regular students in the universities where they study while they are studying. For example, I get to be registered as a student of the Université de Lorraine for the first year.
This means that, for the French educational system, the enrolment is made into the Université de Lorraine, so that’s what one has to select in the Études en France platform. (This was confusing at the beginning because I kept looking everywhere in the platform for a “LCT Master” but could find none)
As it happens, in the French system, unlike other educational systems, Master’s technically do not last two years. Instead, they are two educational programs of one year, the “M1” and the “M2”, which are supposed to be taken in sequence.
As I was going for my first year to the Université de Lorraine as an LCT student, technically I was getting into the M1 program.
All of this boils down to the fact that the Études en France platform, being from the French government, expects a French higher education program. I had to look up the official name of the program on the university website, which is the Master 1 Traitement Automatique des Langues at the IDMC (Institute des sciences du Digital)

title: Visa to France - 1: Campus France
text:
Correcting the dossier
If you, like me, find out that you uploaded a wrong document or forgot to upload some document, don’t panic.
It is very easy to correct the dossier.

If you have not yet submitted your dossier, the platform just lets you erase and reupload whatever you need.
If you have already submitted your dossier, write an email to your local Campus France explaining the mistake, and they’ll reopen the platform for you.

The good (and patient!) people at the Campus France Peru reopened the platform two times for me.

title: Settling in Spain: bureaucracy as an international student
text:
Note





Please read this guide to the LCT in Spain written by previous students
The Polytechnic University of Catalunya’s (UPC) International Office has put together this great resource covering all possible cases of Spanish bureaucracy for international students. It contains explanations and tutorials (with pictures to navigate forms and official websites)! Available in English, Spanish, and Catalan.
Unlike France, there was not a lot of bureaucracy to do in order to settle in Spain. The main bottleneck came from the lack of understandable instructions to do the bureaucratic procedures.
That meant that figuring out what to do usually took longer than actually doing it. The information on official websites can be confusing and only available in Spanish. We noticed that the easiest way to understand any procedure was to ask someone who had done it before.
Before mentioning all the bureaucracy you have to do to start your time in Donostia, there are some concepts that will be necessary.

title: Settling in Spain: bureaucracy as an international student
text:
NIE
The NIE (Número de Identidad de Extranjero) is your Foreigner Identity Number. It will be uniquely linked to you, and you will need it for most bureaucracy.
If you become a tax resident in Spain, the NIE is also your tax system ID (Número de Identificación Fiscal NIF).
The DNI (documento nacional de identidad) is the equivalent for Spanish citizens, so many people use this term. You’ll generally get asked for your “De-ne-ee”: your NIE is the correct response!

title: Settling in Spain: bureaucracy as an international student
text:
TIE
The TIE (Tarjeta de Identidad de Extranjero) is the physical card for your residence permit. It serves as an ID card for foreigners. If you get a new TIE, for example by asking for an extension of your permit, then your new TIE will keep the same NIE.

title: Settling in Spain: bureaucracy as an international student
text:
Empadronamiento
This is simply registering your address with the local town hall. You can do it without a NIE, just using with your passport. You will need a valid proof of accomodation.

title: Settling in Spain: bureaucracy as an international student
text:
Estancia VS Residencia
In most countries, there are only two possible ways in which a foreigner can legally be on their territory: as a tourist, or as a resident. Tourists have very limited rights (for example, they cannot work), and residents have almost the same rights as a citizen (for example, they can use the public health system).
However, Spain has a third option, called Estancia (litterally, “stay”). Estancia is an intermediate status between a tourist and a resident. For example, people with Estancia are allowed to work, but cannot use the public health system.
Why is this important?

non-EU foreign students can only get Estancia.
EU citizens can get a Residencia just by moving to Spain.
In principle, non-EU foreign students can change their Estancia to a Residencia only after finishing their studies.
For the purpose of getting Spanish nationality, only the time under Residencia counts, not the time under Estancia.

title: Settling in Spain: bureaucracy as an international student
text:
Digital Certificates
One of the big advantages of Spain is that most common bureacracy can be done online. After you get your first TIE, you can get Digital Certificates, which are used to digitally sign documents and online forms.

title: Settling in Spain: bureaucracy as an international student
section: The Foreigners Office and The Police Office
text:
The Foreigners Office and The Police Office
In most countries, all bureaucracy concerning foreigners is done at the Foreigners Office (Oficina de Extranjería). However, in Spain, these duties are split between the Foreigners Office and the Police Office (Comisaría de la Policía Nacional).
It is useful to keep this difference in mind, because both offices use the same website to request appointments.
The Police Office is in charge of producing TIEs, while all other bureaucracy is done by the Foreigners Office.
This can lead to weird situations. For example, if you ask for an extension of your permit, and it is approved after the expiration date of your current permit, then you will get a document from the Foreigners Office saying that you are legally allowed to be in Spain, even when you do not have a valid TIE yet (of course, you wwill have to request a new TIE at the Police as soon as possible).
Another weird situation is that there are procedures from the Foreigners Office which ask you to deposit the documents at the Police Office. Then, when you get an answer about your procedure, it will be writen by the Foreigners Office.






Note





The Foreigners Office has a decent digital platform, called MERCURIO, where most bureaucracy can be done online.
The Police Office requires most of it bureaucracy to be done in person.

title: Settling in Spain: bureaucracy as an international student
text:
Bureaucratic culture
Spanish administrative personnel in Donostia tend to be very helpful, even when you do not speak much Spanish or they do not speak much English.
Feel free to ask for clarifications, help filling out forms, and all the instructions you may need.
Even in those cases when booking appointments is necessary, Spanish bureaucrats in Donostia are flexible with time. If you arrive earlier to your appointment, they will take you in, even if you are early by several hours. Arriving later will be a problem if the queues are long, so, do not arrive later than 15 minutes.
If you have very specific issues or a complicated bureaucratic question, it is best for you to go accompanied by a native spanish speaker.

title: Settling in Spain: bureaucracy as an international student
text:
Inmigration bureaucracy

Get a NIE
Get an Empadronamiento
Make sure you have a Right to Stay in Spain
Get a TIE
Get your Digital Certificates
Get your Social Security Number

title: Settling in France: Phone number and mobile data
text: Having mobile data in a new city is really helpful, specially during the first weeks while settling in. Some bureaucratic processes ask optionally for a phone number.

title: Settling in France: Phone number and mobile data
text:
Getting a SIM
After creating an account, there was an option to request a new SIM card. It took around 10 days to arrive to my residence in physical mail.

title: Settling in France: Phone number and mobile data
text:
Changing mobile phone providers
I wanted to keep the phone number from my first SIM card, and I found out that changing mobile phone providers is pretty easy in France!

RIO number
The RIO number is a code that identifies your phone number. To get it, call for free the number 3179, and a bot will answer. Though it is available in French, it will give you the option of getting your RIO number via SMS.


Requesting a change
In the website of the new provider (Lebara in my case), there should be an option for changing phone numbers. There, fill in the request with your RIO code and go through the steps.
After a day or two I got a SMS saying my request was being processed. Also two or three days later, I got another SMS saying the request was approved, and they notified me of the exact date when the change was going to be effective.

Activating the data
This is only particular to Lebara: it is necessary to set up an Access Point Name (APN) in order to use the Lebara network. To the best of my knowledge, other carriers do this automatically. However, the process takes around five minutes in your phone settings.
Here are the instructions, from thei own website:


Code
##On AndroidTM
"""
1. Menu/Parameters
2. More...
3. Mobile networks
4. Name of access points
5. Create a new APN
6. Enter the following information:
           Name: lebara
           APN: fr.lebara.mobi
           Username: WAP
           Password: WAP
           APN Protocol: IPv4 
           APN roaming protocol: IPv4

7. Authentication type: PAP
8. Save 
9. Press lebara.mobi to get it into active mode  
10.Internet connection is set up in a matter of moments
""";

## On Apple iOS

"""
1. Settings
2. Cellular data
3. Cellular data network
4. Enter the following information: Location of access point: fr.lebara.mobi

text:
Note





Please read this guide to the LCT in Spain written by previous students
The Polytechnic University of Catalunya’s (UPC) International Office has put together this great resource covering all possible cases of Spanish bureaucracy for international students. It contains explanations and tutorials (with pictures to navigate forms and official websites)! Available in English, Spanish, and Catalan.
You will need a NIE to do most bureaucracy in Spain.
Here, I give an overview of the process to get a NIE, depending on which situation you are in.

title: Settling in Spain: How to get a NIE
text:
You are European
As an european, you do not need any visa or permit to legally live, study, and work in Spain, lucky you! You will still need a NIE, though.
If you are outside of Spain, you can contact your closest Spanish consulate, they are the ones in charge of assigning NIEs abroad.
If you already arrived to Spain, then you will have to go through the “Registro de Ciudadano de la Unión” process described in this post about the Right to Stay in Spain.

title: Settling in Spain: How to get a NIE
text:
You are not European
In this situation, you took the risk of arriving to Spain as a tourist, hoping to do all the bureaucracy to become an Spanish resident. This situation is not unheard of, however, it is very delicate.






Caution





This is not a good situation to be in: It is possible to regularize your situation (and you almost surely will), but it will take time and patience.



To get a NIE you will have to go through the “Assignación de NIE” process described below.

title: Settling in Spain: How to get a NIE
text:
NIE Assignment Process (Asignación de NIE)
This process can only be done if you are already in Spain and do not have a NIE, and must be done in person.
Official website

In Donostia, managed by the Police Office
You will have to make an appointment and pay a fee
You have to pay the fee (tasa) 790-012, of approximately 10€, as of 2023
You have to fill out form (formulaio) EX-15, where you will have to specify the reason that makes you ask for a NIE.
Studying at a Spanish University is sufficient reason for asking for a NIE.
You have to give some kind of proof of your situation: admission letters to University are enough.







Note





You will receive your NIE at most 5 days after your appointment.
Book your appointment early!

title: Settling in Spain: How to get Empadronamiento
text:
Note





Please read this guide to the LCT in Spain written by previous students
The Polytechnic University of Catalunya’s (UPC) International Office has put together this great resource covering all possible cases of Spanish bureaucracy for international students. It contains explanations and tutorials (with pictures to navigate forms and official websites)! Available in English, Spanish, and Catalan.
Empadronamiento is the administrative process by which you officially register your address in Spain. It is administered by the local town hall.
Here, I give an overview of the process to get your Empadronamiento in Donostia.

title: Settling in Spain: How to get Empadronamiento
text:
ID
You can get your Empadronamiento with your NIE or your passport.
It is preferred that your Empadronamiento Certificate shows your NIE, as you will need this certificate for some bureaucracy with the Foreigners Office and the Police Office. Therefore, if you make your Empadronamiento with your passport, it is recommended, as soon as you get a NIE, to get Empadronamiento again with your NIE.

title: Settling in Spain: How to get Empadronamiento
text:
Proof of accomodation
There are different valid proofs of accomodation depending on your situation.

You are staying at someone’s place
If you are staying at someone’s place and this person is the owner (propietario/a) of the place, then they can give you Empadronamiento at their address.
In this situation, it is best if the owner accompanies you to the Udalinfo office.

The owner will have to provide proof of ownership (not complicated)
The owner will have to show their ID
The owner will have to sign on a form that the people at Udalinfo will provide

That is it!


You are renting






Note





You need a contract for Empadronamiento!
Some landlords want to avoid taxes by not offering contracts (in Spanish this is called “alquilar en negro”).



There are two common renting situations:


The owner rents the place themselves, thus, the rental contract is between you and the owner.

You will need:

(A copy of) your rental contract
Proof of rent payment of the last month. You can ask the owner to write you a receipt.



The owner designates an Administrator to take care of the property. In this case, the rental contract is between you and the Administrator. The Administrator may be another person, or a company (agencia inmobiliaria).

You will need:

Your rental contract
Proof of rent payment of the last month. You can ask the Administrator to write you a receipt.
Proof that the Administrator is associated to the owner. You can ask for a receipt that shows that the Administrator transmitted the rent payment to the owner.




My case
In my case, I was renting at a place that had an Administrator.
I had to go to the Udalinfo Office three times for clarifications about the necessary documents.

The first time, I went only with my contract, and they told me I needed proof of payment of the last month.
The second time, I took both the contract and the receipt for the last month, and they told me I needed proof that the Administrator was associated with the owner. They explained what kind of documents could work.
As proof that the Administrator was associated with the owner, a bank transfer statement worked. This bank transfer from the Administrator to the owner had the description “Alquiler de Septiembre (Rent for September)”.
The third time I went to the Udalinfo office, the worker that assisted me did not know all the details of how to do Empadronamiento when there is an Administrator, and thus refused to do it.
Finally, this worker called a more experienced one, who saw my papers, said they were OK, and proceeded to make my Empadronamiento.

title: Settling in Spain: Right to Stay in Spain
text:
Note





Please read this guide to the LCT in Spain written by previous students
The Polytechnic University of Catalunya’s (UPC) International Office has put together this great resource covering all possible cases of Spanish bureaucracy for international students. It contains explanations and tutorials (with pictures to navigate forms and official websites)! Available in English, Spanish, and Catalan.



When you are arriving to Spain for the first time, and in order to stay for more than six months, you need to have the right to stay in Spain. There are three possible situations, and I will explain in each one what you need to do.

You are not European and you arrived with a Student Visa
Congratulations!






Note





Your Student Visa proofs that you have the right to stay in Spain.



Now you need to get a TIE!


You are not European and you arrived without a Student Visa
In this situation, you took the risk of arriving to Spain as a tourist, hoping to do all the bureaucracy to become an Spanish resident. This situation is not unheard of, however, it is very delicate.






Caution





This is not a good situation to be in: It is possible to regularize your situation (and you almost surely will), but it will take time and patience.



To get the right to stay in Spain you will have to apply for an Authorization of Stay due to Studies (Autorización de estancia por estudios).
The documents necessary to get this Authorization are very similar to the ones needed for applying for a Spanish Student Visa.
You can apply for it in person, at the Foreigners Office, or online, throught the “Mercurio” Platform.
I would recommend applying in person. If you want to apply online, which accelerates the processing of the application, you will need a Digital Certificate. However, as a non-EU foreigner, you can only get a personal Digital Certificate once you have a TIE. Thus, you would need an immigration lawyer to use their Digital Certificate to make the application on your behalf. This is expensive.
When your Authorization is approved (which is almost certain if you fulfill all the requirements), you will get a Resolución (Resolution or Decision). In this Resolución the Foreigners Office will give you the right to stay in Spain.
Processing the application takes at most one month. If you do not get an answer within a month, it means the application was rejected.
In the rare case that your application is rejected, you will be given two weeks to leave Spain. However, an immigration lawyer can help you contest this decision.






Note





The favorable Resolución proofs that you have the right to stay in Spain.



After getting the Resolución, you need to get a TIE.


You are European
Just by being from the European Union, you have the right to live and work in any other Member State of EU.
To prove that you have the right to stay in Spain, you have to register as a European Citizen living in Spain, by requesting an inscription into the Foreigners’ Central Register (Registro Central de Extranjeros).
This request is made by the procedure called “Certificate of Inscription of European Union Citizens” (Certificado de Registro de Ciudadanos de la Unión Europea). In Donostia, this is done at the Police Office.
The website mentioned above (from the Polytechnic University of Catalunya) goes into the finer details for this procedure.






Tip





This procedure is very straightforwad and simple.
Once you go to your appointment at the Police Office and present all your documents, you will immediately be assigned a NIE and given an Inscription Certificate (Certificado de Registro … UE), which is a small and green paper.









Note





The Certificado de Registro … UE proofs that you have the right to stay in Spain.



As a European citizen, you do not have to get a TIE.

title: Settling in Spain: How to get a TIE
text:
Note





Please read this guide to the LCT in Spain written by previous students
The Polytechnic University of Catalunya’s (UPC) International Office has put together this great resource covering all possible cases of Spanish bureaucracy for international students. It contains explanations and tutorials (with pictures to navigate forms and official websites)! Available in English, Spanish, and Catalan.
If you are a non-EU citizen staying for more than six months in Spain, you have to get a TIE to be legal in Spain. The TIE (Tarjeta de Identidad de Extranjero) is the physical card for your residence permit. It serves as an ID card for foreigners.
The Police Office is in charge of producing TIEs.

title: Settling in Spain: How to get a TIE
text:
About fee 790-012
There are five options for TIEs that are covered by fee 790-012. As non-EU international students, only two concern you:

For your first ever TIE, you need to select “TIE que documenta la primera concesión de la autorización de residencia temporal, de estancia o para trabajadores transfronterizos.”

Litteraly: TIE for first authorization of Estancia, or Residencia, or …

If you are extending your permit, you need to select “TIE que documenta la renovación de la autorización de residencia temporal o la prórroga de la estancia o de la autorización para trabajadores transfronterizos.”

Litteraly: TIE for extension of authorization of Estancia, or Residencia, or …

If you are changing your permit, for example, from a Student Permit to a Job-seeker Permit, then you will be asking for your first TIE with the new kind of permit. In this case, you have to select “TIE que documenta la primera concesión de la autorización de residencia temporal, de estancia o para trabajadores transfronterizos.”

Litteraly: TIE for first authorization of Estancia, or Residencia, or …
